According to the Guidelines for Examination in the EPO, A-III, 5.5, an incorrect designation of an inventor can be rectified if a request is received together with the consent of the wrongly designated person and that of the patent's applicant or proprietor where the request is not filed by that party. In this case, since Mr. Li and Ms. Smith were erroneously designated as co-inventors and it has been found out that only Mr. Li was actually involved in the invention, a request can be made to rectify the designation.\n\nAnswer B is incorrect because the patent proprietor (Mr. Li’s company) still retains the right to make corrections even if no proceedings are pending before the EPO according to Rule 21(1).\n\nWhy options C and D are incorrect:\n- Option C incorrectly states that Mr. Li's consent would be necessary for deleting Ms. Smith as an inventor, which is not required when adding a further inventor.\n- Option D is also incorrect because it suggests that only Ms. Smith’s consent can delete her from the list of inventors, whereas according to the guidelines, consent from both parties (the wrongly designated person and the patent's applicant or proprietor) is needed.\n\nIn summary, since the designation was incorrect, Mr. Li's company as the patent proprietor has the authority to correct it by requesting that Ms. Smith be deleted, but this request needs to include the consent of the wrongly designated person (Ms. Smith).

According to Rule 71(1) of the Rules for Carrying Out the International Patent Classification (RICPC), when a European patent is validated in only two contracting states, the renewal fee for each state can be paid separately. In this case, the European patent was granted on 16 November 2023. Given that the patent is being validated in only two states, renewal fees for those states can be paid separately. The due date to pay the fourth year's fee (which would have been 16 November 2024) has not yet arrived as of 12 October 2023. Therefore, based on Article 98(1)(a), the renewal fee for the fourth year can be validly paid without any additional fee until nine months after the end of the third year (i.e., from 17 November 2024) but at the latest one month from the date on which validation took place, meaning by 16 December 2023.

However, since the due date for the fourth-year fee is still two years away as of now (12 October 2023), and validation occurred in November 2023, the renewal fee can be validly paid without any additional fee until 9 January 2024 at the latest.

- **Option D (Form 1226AC stating that the examination has started):** This form is used when the examination of an application for which no search opinion was drawn up or if the applicant requested a re-examination. In summary, given that the applicant did file amendments during the international phase without requesting an IPE, upon entry into the regional phase, they will receive Form 1226BB to respond to the negative search opinion and request further processing if needed.

According to Rule 19(4), the time limit for adding a priority claim is twelve months from the filing date of the European patent application. In this case, applicant P filed the international patent application (PCT-P) on June 20, 2023, which is more than one year after the filing dates of both EP-I and EP-II (7 July 2022 and 3 July 2022 respectively). However, since the priority claim from EP-II was not originally made, we must consider the date when applicant P discovered this omission. The time limit for adding a missing claim to a European patent application is deemed to expire on the last day of the month in which the document containing the information about that claim or right has been filed.\n\nIn this scenario, the latest priority claim (EP-II) was not claimed until 12 October 2023. Thus, according to Rule 58(6), the time limit for adding EP-II as a priority claim would expire on the last day of the month following its discovery date. Since it is now October, the time limit will expire on November 30, 2023. Therefore, if applicant P files a request to add EP-II as a priority claim by or before November 30, 2023, the addition would be valid.\n\nExplanation for why other options are incorrect:\n- **Option A (Yes, the time limit for adding the priority claim expires on 3 November 2023)**: This is incorrect because it suggests the deadline should match one of EP-II's filing dates. According to Rule 58(6), the exact date of the discovery (12 October 2023) dictates the end of the twelve-month period, making November 30, 2023, the correct deadline.\n- **Option C (Yes, the time limit for adding the priority claim expires on 20 October 2023)**: This is incorrect because it suggests the deadline was based on the filing date of PCT-P rather than when applicant P discovered the missing claim.\n- **Option D (No, the time limit for adding the priority claim expired on 3 July 2023)**: This is incorrect as it incorrectly assumes that the time limit started from EP-II's filing date and has already passed. The discovery of the omission on October 12, 2023, resets the twelve-month period.
